title-group.article-title: The Changing Route to Owner-occupation: The Impact of Borrowing Constraints on Young Adult Homeownership Transitions in Britain in the 1990s

author-notes.corresp: Mark Andrew is in the CASS Business School, City University London, 106 Bunhill Row London, EC1Y 8TZ, UK. E-mail: Mark.Andrew.1@city.ac.uk.

abstract.p: The reduction in young adult homeownership rates in Britain in the 1990s was partly caused by demographics and partly by a shift in the income distribution. Most of their relative income deterioration occurred in the first part of the decade, yet young adult homeownership rates continued to fall. This paper extends that analysis by empirically examining whether lender-imposed borrowing restrictions also contributed to their decline, especially since house prices rose rapidly in the second half of the decade. A duration model examining the timing of a transition into homeownership is estimated on a sample of young adults derived from the British Household Panel Survey. Credit constraint terms are constructed and included in the model. A simulation analysis is undertaken to assess the extent to which binding credit constraints were responsible for the observed falls. It is concluded that borrowing restrictions delayed young adult transitions into homeownership.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Britain in the 1990s experienced a reversal of the trend towards younger owner-occupation, which is partly attributable to demographics (Holmans, 1999, 2001, 2005) and partly to the deterioration in their relative incomes (Andrew and Meen, 2003). This paper extends the previous analyses by examining empirically whether lender-imposed borrowing restrictions and rapid rises in house prices from the middle of the decade also contributed to this decline. The procedure outlined by Linneman and Wachter (1989) to capture the effect of lenders’ restrictions is adopted but modified to suit the British context. A duration model is employed to analyse young adult transitions into homeownership and simulation analysis undertaken to assess the extent to which binding credit constraints were responsible for the fall. Using the British Household Panel Survey, we find support for credit market constraints delaying young adult transitions into homeownership in the 1990s.

Section 2 sets out the motivation for the study by examining the key trends in the housing market. Sections 3 and 4 describe the economic theory of housing tenure choice and the data used in analysis respectively. Section 5 outlines the empirical strategy. The sixth section reports the results. Section 7 undertakes the simulation analysis and conclusions are drawn at the end of the paper.

sec.title: 2. Trends in the Housing Market in the 1990s
sec.p: The trends in young adult homeownership rates in England by age-group are displayed in Table 1. Although the table relates to England, it is broadly indicative of the overall changes in housing tenure in Britain.1 Young adult homeownership rates rose in the 1980s and fell in the 1990s, with the largest falls experienced among the youngest. These reductions coincided with increases in private renting while the proportions renting socially remained broadly stable over the 1990s. Nevertheless, various Surveys of English Housing (SEH) report that the long-term homeownership aspirations among young adults remain undiminished. Private renting was and still is perceived to be a transition housing tenure. Conversely, the homeownership rates of older age-groups (40 and above) have continued to rise (not reported).

sec.p: Later first-time house purchases are responsible for a large part of this reduction (Holmans, 2001, 2005). There were fewer young first-time buyers (FTBs) in the 1990s compared with a decade earlier, but more purchases by older age-groups. Young FTB house purchases also fell again after 1999/2000. Holmans concluded that the reduction in young FTBs is only partly explained by demographics.

A significant proportion of this fall was attributable to the deterioration of young adults’ position in the income distribution which reduced their effective housing demand (Andrew and Meen, 2003). Although they had not fully recovered their 1980s position in the income distribution by the end of the decade, most of the shift occurred in the early 1990s (Andrew et al., 2006). Consequently, it is less important as a factor on its own in explaining falls of house purchases experienced in the late 1990s.

The rapid increase in house prices after 1996 could provide an explanation as it might have made it more difficult for potential FTBs to meet lenders’ borrowing criteria. The effect of borrowing restrictions on housing tenure has been a major theme of US research (Linnenman and Wachter, 1989, Haurin et al., 1997). The general consensus is that the young are severely affected by lender-imposed downpayment and income constraints (Haurin et al., 1997). By contrast, there are few British studies. Ortalo-Magné and Rady (1999) argued that mortgage market deregulation led to a surge of young adults bringing forward their house purchase in Britain in the 1980s. Benito (2006) concluded that downpayment constraints were important in explaining house price volatility using data aggregated at the local authority district level. Meen (2008) showed that there were periods in the 1990s when there was mortgage rationing at the macro level, albeit at low levels. Yet there remains little empirical evidence of their impact on young new entrants to the housing market.

Table 2 displays the average advance and average income advances (multiples) of FTBs and former owner-occupiers (FOO). Between 1996 and 2002, the average FTB deposit doubled and the average FTB advance (loan-to-value) ratio decreased from 90 per cent to 77 per cent. The fall in FTB loan-to-value (LTV) ratios cannot be fully explained by parental assistance as Tatch (2007) reported that only about 10 per cent of young FTBs received parental help with a deposit in the 1990s. By contrast, FOO deposits as a percentage of the purchase house price hardly changed, even though their average deposit increased. The larger deposit is due to gains in housing equity. For many FTBs, a 21 per cent deposit is a hefty barrier to purchasing a home. This table also reveals that the average FTB income multiples rose to 2.5, implying that they stretched themselves financially.

sec.p: However, the observed income multiple rises are market outcomes and may reflect the relaxation of lending criteria as some lenders switched to debt-servicing ratios or lower prevailing interest rates encouraging greater borrowing. One Halifax Bank of Scotland (HBOS) affordability measure, the mortgage interest payments to income ratio, remained below the levels reached in the 1980s, although it did rise slightly towards the end of the decade. Some commentators have pointed out that 100–125 per cent LTV mortgages were available. Table 2 indicates that such mortgage products were not the norm.

Finally, it should be pointed out that Table 1 only shows the trends for those who had already formed a household. Holmans (1999) reported that household formation rates among the young fell in the 1990s, although this reversed slightly for men by the end of the decade.2 Empirical studies have concluded that both demographic and economic factors were responsible (Ermisch, 1999; Andrew and Meen, 2003). The next section outlines how credit constraints might affect the choice of housing tenure.

Households may use any excess of a required deposit to alleviate a binding income constraint. Therefore, an income constraint only becomes binding if phh* > (phhY+ excess deposit), and not otherwise. In the empirical implementation, an algorithm is used to make this adjustment.

Binding mortgage constraints do not preclude households from purchasing a smaller-sized dwelling or one in a less desirable location. Nevertheless, they are credit constrained as they end up consuming a sub-optimal level of owner-occupied housing services. Alternatively, households may rent to consume an optimal level of housing services rather than a sub-optimal level of owner-occupied services. Thus, the actual housing tenure choice observed does not always represent the desired housing position. It also implies that the other components of the housing user cost are still relevant even when the credit constraints are binding.

Our discussion concentrated on relative housing tenure costs due to the research question. Life-cycle and demographic factors such as age, race, marital status, family composition and permanent income are also very important in determining housing tenure preferences (Smits and Mulder, 2008; Haurin et al., 1997). In the absence of lending restrictions, housing tenure choice and demand for housing services is dictated by permanent income, ceteris paribus. When present, current income and current net wealth are expected to be important too.

sec.title: 4. Data
sec.p: The original British Household Panel Survey (BHPS) surveys more than 10 000 adults in over 5000 households. A sample is selected from the first 12 Waves covering the period 1991–2002/03. Stopping in the early part of 2000 avoids the problem of accounting for the considerable rise in parental assistance as this information is not recorded in the BHPS. Parental assistance to young adult FTB purchases increased from under 10 per cent in the mid 1990s to around 18 per cent in 2002/03 and then rose to reach 38 per cent in 2006 (Tatch, 2007).

Respondents were selected to the ‘stock’ sample if they satisfied the criteria: they were aged 18 or over but under 40 on 1 December in the Wave they were first observed; and, they responded to a full interview throughout the sample period. Households headed by full-time students are recategorised as not having formed an independent household.4 The selection procedure resulted in 3371 individuals in Britain, with an average initial age of 27 years; 48 per cent of the sample is male.

Table 3 displays the transition probabilities by age-groups, expressed in percentages. The rows denote the initial state and the columns the position in the next year. Each year, an individual had a 9–10 per cent chance of becoming a homeowner. As in Ermisch and Halpin (2004), a high proportion move out of a non-independent household into homeownership. The reversion to renting/returning to living in a non-independent household is low, about 3 per cent, implying that the reduced homeownership rates in Table 1 reflect lower transitions into the tenure than exits from it.

sec.p: Housing tenure transitions occurred gradually. Respondents in private renting had the highest probability of leaving and entering homeownership (20 per cent) in the following year. There are differences across age-groups. Those above 24 years are more likely to form an independent household compared with the under 25s, more likely to transit into and less likely to exit from homeownership. Yet the under 25s exits from homeownership are still low (5.5 per cent).

We model the entry hazard into homeownership rather than the state probabilities. First, this avoids the problem of any asymmetries between transitions into and out of housing tenures (Ermisch and Di Salvo, 1996) and into and out of household formation. Secondly, existing homeowners are less likely to be credit constrained than FTBs (Table 2). Thirdly, there are relatively few transitions out of homeownership (Table 3). The overall dynamic process can be characterised as a transition from the parental home into the permanent housing tenure of owner-occupation, as private renting is a transitory housing tenure and social renting is rationed and not available to most people. Moreover, the option of those already in social renting (a permanent tenure) is to buy rather than to return to a transitory housing state.

Only respondents who were not homeowners in the initial Wave were used to model transitions. They were tracked until 2002/03 unless they either entered into homeownership or turned 40. This selection procedure yielded 1916 individuals. The average initial age is 24 years and 50 per cent are male. Thus, the method by which the sample for the duration model is obtained is a combined stock and flow sampling scheme. A single non-homeownership spell for each individual is modelled.

sec.title: 5. The Estimation Methodology
sec.p: Empirical implementation requires a system of equations to be estimated. In practice, the equations are estimated separately to make the analysis tractable. They comprise of a potential offered wage equation to account for possible endogeneity between household incomes among the young and their housing choices; a housing demand equation to obtain a predicted value of desired housing demand; and a duration model to analyse the transitions into owner-occupation. Further details of the overall strategy are outlined next.

sec.title: Potential Offered Wage Rate
sec.p: The potential wage equation, not reported for brevity, represents a young household’s possible earning power and is estimated by regressing the gross hourly wage in a Heckman selection framework. Its covariates include age, age squared and dummies representing qualifications, race, sex, regions and time. In addition to the characteristics contained in the wage equation, the selection equation includes spouse’s age and qualifications, number of children and age of the youngest child. Haurin et al. (1992, 1994) argued that the potential wage rate or the sum of the individual’s and spouse’s potential wage rate is a more appropriate way of capturing young adults’ permanent income as it abstracts from the labour supply decision.

sec.title: Lenders’ Loan Parameters
sec.p:
Lenders’ loan parameters (LM, b) are not reported in the BHPS. Although actual LTV ratios and income multiples are observed for homeowners, they are outcomes and may reflect household preferences. In the US studies, values tend to be assigned for mortgage debt servicing (0.28) and LTV ratios (LM=0.80) which reflect the criteria required for mortgages to be conformable to securitisation. Mortgage contract heterogeneity in the UK (Leece, 2004) implies that this approach may not be appropriate. We take advantage of the endogeneity arising from lenders varying the criteria they apply to different potential borrowers and potential borrowers searching for lenders who let them borrow close to what they desire. sec.title: Desired Housing Demand
sec.p: Desired housing expenditure (phh*) is not recorded in the BHPS. As in Linneman and Wachter (1989) and Haurin et al. (1997), predicted values of desired housing demand are obtained by running a housing demand regression on a sample where homeowners are deemed to be in equilibrium. Desired expenditure is equal to the predicted value multiplied by the standardised dwelling price. This regression serves two other purposes. Expenditure on housing services is likely to be endogenously determined with housing tenure choice and predicted values provide an instrument. Furthermore, it provides an imputed value for non-homeowners. Some empirical studies argue that recent movers are most likely to be near their desired housing position (Ermisch et al., 1996). However, recent movers could be ‘constrained’ in their housing consumption, particularly if it is the first move into homeownership. Other studies have acknowledged that ‘stayers’ could be in equilibrium too (Goodman, 2002).

In this study, the sample of ‘unconstrained’ households is selected from respondents: expressing a preference for staying in their current residence rather than moving; liking the neighbourhood; having LTV ratios below the regional median values; and, having a single income multiple or joint income multiple less than regional median values, determined by whether a single income or joint income provides maximum purchasing power. Repeat-purchaser median values are matched to previous owners and FTB median values to potential FTBs. Low values for the final two criteria imply that a household could move if they wished (Linneman and Wachter, 1989; Haurin et al., 1997). Sample selection is accounted for using a Heckman estimator in order to provide a better estimate of the desired housing position than just running a regression on all homeowners.

The empirical results of various versions of the housing demand model are displayed in Table A1 in the Appendix. The dependent variable is the logarithm of housing consumption, obtained by dividing the reported house value by the regional value of a standardised dwelling. The housing demand equations include as covariates household head’s age and its square, the logarithm of the housing user cost, head’s race, the number of children, head’s sex and the highest qualification of a household member (default = higher degree). The latter is used as a proxy for permanent income instead of the potential wage rate. The selection mechanism includes as additional regressors the real rent, the housing user cost, the regional unemployment rate and dummies for being a homeowner in the previous period to account for housing wealth to meet any borrowing restrictions. Results are reported in the Appendix. Model A1 is preferred as it explicitly attempts to control for the housing tenure choice and being unconstrained. Model A2 excludes the selection equation but the same uncensored sample is estimated as model A1. The next two models are estimated on all homeowners in the sample. Model A3 corrects for the housing tenure choice and model A4 does not.

The estimates have the expected signs. The price elasticities range from −0.22 to −0.23 and are slightly lower than those reported in UK cross-section studies by Ermisch et al. (1996) and Hendershott and Pryce (2006). Model A1 yields the highest predicted values and model A4 the lowest. Predicted values of the preferred model A1 are used to construct the credit constraint dummies.7

sec.title: Financial Wealth
sec.p: The BHPS only contains debt and investment information in Waves five and ten. Relying on a net wealth measure would restrict the analysis to just two time-periods, 1996 and 2001. To take advantage of the time-series dimension in the BHPS, a gross wealth term (W) is computed by capitalising young adults’ investment income.8 Wealth depends upon the decision to save and, if the motive for saving is to obtain a deposit for a home, it is endogenous to a homeownership transition. We examined the savings motives of those who actually saved. Of those who did, less than 15 per cent of potential first-time buyers saved for a house deposit during this period. It should also be pointed out that 62 per cent of this group did not save at all. Endogeneity arising from financial savings is not likely to be very important for this sample. Furthermore, as wealth is a stock variable, it will only change gradually over time. Any endogeneity is thus likely to be minimal.

sec.title: The Duration Model
sec.p:
A discrete-time logit model is employed because residential moves and housing tenure transitions are not accurately recorded and the exact value of the explanatory variables when a spell ceased are not known. The initial state is taken to be living in the parental home at 18. . The event indicator yit = 1 represents the transition into homeownership at time t and yit = 0 otherwise. The logit model takes the form

The covariates X may be fixed or time-varying; αt is the baseline logit-hazard. The logit form yields a proportional odds model as the effects of covariates are assumed constant across the observation period. The coefficient β is interpreted as the effect of a one-unit change in a covariate on the log-odds of an event in interval t. The exponent of β is the odds ratio.

Duration independence is assumed if the baseline hazard is specified to be a constant αt = α. Parameter estimates β are biased if the duration independence assumption is not satisfied, which may be relaxed by treating αt as a function of time. A flexible form for αt is a step function involving an overall intercept term and time-interval dummies. This parameterisation leads to a piecewise-constant hazards model where the hazard is assumed constant within each of the time-intervals (Allison, 1982).

There could be a problem of left-side censoring, where the risk of transiting commenced before the respondent is surveyed, leading to an over-representation of individuals in the sample prone to slower transitions into homeownership.9 The logit model can accommodate this by re-specifying the time-interval dummies to capture the time prior to inclusion in the sample (Frederiksen et al., 2007). We assume that the ‘risk’ of transiting begins at 18. Some ‘older’ individuals may have already had a spell as a homeowner but reverted to another housing tenure prior to being surveyed. As the BHPS does not contain pre-sample information, there is little choice but to assume few respondents experienced this. The low rate of reversion out of homeownership in Table 3 provides some justification.

sec.title: 6. Main Empirical Results
sec.p: The duration model results are displayed in Table 4. The estimates have been converted into odds ratios and boot-strapped z-values (in brackets) are reported to account for regressors constructed using predicted values. The estimates describe the effect of having a characteristic or a change in a covariate value on the odds of making a homeownership transition relative to the odds of remaining outside this tenure. For example, an estimate equal to 1.2 for the covariate female implies that the odds of making transition by a female is 1.2 times higher than the odds of a male.

sec.p: Likelihood ratio (LR) tests reveal that all models are statistically significant. The class of models denoted 1 have a constant baseline hazard, 2 a flexible baseline hazard and 3 a flexible baseline hazard with eight three-year-interval dummies to account for left-sided censoring. The latter exclude age regressors as it is assumed that all individuals have been at risk since 18. Credit constraint dummies are excluded in the model labelled A but included in those labelled B, C and D. The difference between B and C lies in the instrumentation of the loan parameters required to construct the dummies. B is constructed using the regional median LTV ratios and income multiples and C using the predicted values taken from the regression of actual values against all exogenous variables in the system. Model D is a restricted version of C. It excludes the spouse term as previous analysis on the BHPS reported that partnership formation is negatively related to house prices (Ermisch and Pevalin, 2004), which might imply that credit market constraints also reduce the propensity to form a partnership. Including a spouse term would thus understate the impact of binding credit constraints on entry into owner-occupation. The estimated impact of binding credit constraints in model D is higher than C.

LR tests conducted on the inclusion of interval dummies indicate that the duration independence assumption is invalid. For example, the tests that model 1A is nested in either model 2A or 3A are χ2(10)=41.64 and χ2(8)=30.90. The interval dummies indicate a declining hazard and a non-linear hazard (initially increases and then decreases) respectively for non-corrected and censored corrected models. Controlling for left-sided censoring does not appear to make much difference to the estimates.

Due to interpretation limitations of odds ratios, Table 5 displays the marginal effects. A marginal effect reflects the difference in the risk of a making transition as a result of having a characteristic or a unit increase in a covariate value. They are calculated at mean values for the covariates that are held constant.

sec.p: Demographic and economic factors are important. Two significant demographic influences are the presence of a spouse and the number of children. As in other studies using the logit duration model such as Ermisch and Di Salvo (1996) and Smits and Mulder (2008), the homeownership transition is linked to a union between couples. The odds of a couple transiting are 12 to 14 times higher than a single person. The marginal effects suggest that the risk of transiting is increased by between 14 and 17 per cent. For some, the move into homeownership is connected with cohabitation, implying that this explanatory variable may be endogenous. Dealing with an endogenous dummy variable in this context is not straightforward as factors determining partnership formation also influence housing tenure transitions. As in most other empirical studies, it is left untreated. Children are influential. An additional child reduces the risk by about 2 per cent or the relative odds by a factor of 0.6. Having a child before purchasing a home could be capturing a higher financial burden or families who reside in the social rented sector, an alternative long-term housing tenure.

Young adults are more likely to establish an independent household as they get older and enter into a more permanent housing tenure such as owner-occupation. The default age dummy is under 25 years. They are most likely to make a transition in their late 20s and early 30s, but are equally likely to transit in their late 30s as their early 20s. This could be due to a confounding effect from having individuals who never make a transition into homeownership and remain in the social rented sector permanently.10

Females make a quicker transition when the credit constraint or spouse terms are excluded. Female-headed households are less likely to be homeowners (Andrew and Meen, 2003), but exhibit a higher propensity to form households (Ermisch, 1999) as they tend to establish ties with older men. Their lower propensity of homeownership is often put down to a lack of finance. When controlling for credit rationing and spouse, they seem equally likely to transit as males as the female dummy is marginally insignificant. Young Asians transit more slowly compared with other racial groups. Being Asian reduces the risk by about 2–3 per cent.

The regional unemployment rate is included to proxy regional demand conditions but did not have a significant effect in any model. Housing costs are important. The cost of owner-occupation is represented by the housing user cost of capital but, in this application, the credit rationing terms are treated as separate regressors. Thus, the housing user cost represents the cost when there is no constraint. The odds of making a transition when the user cost increases by £1000 relative to the odds when it remains unchanged are reduced by a factor of 0.8 to 0.9, whereas a real rent rise of a similar magnitude raises the odds by 1.5 times. The respective marginal effects are −0.7 and 1.7 per cent. Permanent income is represented by the combined potential gross wage rate. An additional £1 raises the relative odds by about 3 to 4 per cent.

Linneman and Wachter (1989) and Haurin et al. (1997) pointed out that realised current real income and current real wealth may be as important as permanent income in determining the housing tenure choice when lending restrictions exist. Both credit constraint terms are influential in the hazard models. The LR tests reject their joint exclusion—for example, the LR tests are respectively χ2(2)=188.97, χ2(2)=176.64 and χ2(2)=185.50 in models 1B, 2B and 3B. Similarly large figures are obtained for the appropriate models labelled C.

Binding wealth and income constraints reduce a transition by about a quarter to one-third and two-thirds respectively. The equivalent marginal effects are about 1–2 per cent when a wealth constraint is binding and about 7–8 per cent when the income constraint is binding. Note that the wealth constraint constructed using the predicted loan-to-value ratios in model 2C is only marginally significant at the 5 per cent level. Overall, a binding income constraint exerted a greater influence than a binding wealth constraint; a result which is consistent with an earlier empirical finding that lagged current income exerted a far greater influence than lagged current gross wealth on first-time homeownership transitions reported in Andrew et al. (2006). In the US literature, which tends to focus on estimating state probabilities, the wealth constraint is normally found to exert the bigger influence (Haurin et al., 1997). However, there is a caveat. The wealth measure used to construct the wealth constraint dummy does not include parental assistance as the information is not available and this might lead to an overestimate of the young who are constrained. On the other hand, the wealth measure is a gross measure and excludes debt, which would underestimate those who might be wealth constrained.

The odds ratios of credit constraint dummies in models B and C differ slightly—the binding wealth and income constraint has a slightly larger and smaller effect respectively. No discernable differences are observed in marginal effects. Models D which exclude the spouse term report slightly higher impacts, implying that credit restrictions also affect household formation. Comparing models 1A, 1B and 1C, the inclusion of credit constraint dummies lowers the odds ratios and marginal effects of the presence of a spouse, being Asian, the age dummies and being female. The odds ratio of the potential wage rate is also reduced but not its marginal effect.11 Thus, it would suggest that their exclusion could lead to biased estimates and overpredictions of the likelihood of making a transition.

sec.title: 7. Simulation Model: Explaining the Decline in Homeownership Rates
sec.p: The previous section establishes that binding constraints are important. This section explores the extent to which they influenced transitions. The simulation examines what would have happened to transitions if house prices had remained at 1996 levels in real terms, holding all other factors constant. House prices affect transitions in three ways. First, they alter the housing user cost and relative tenure costs. Secondly, they affect desired housing consumption via the housing user cost. Thirdly, they interact with lender-imposed borrowing restrictions. In the simulation, the housing user cost is recalculated fixing real house prices at 1996 levels for years after 1996. New predicted values are taken for desired housing consumption and new credit constraint dummies constructed.
The reported simulation output is obtained from the failure function Fi(t) which represents the probability of a person i not surviving (or becoming a homeowner) beyond a point in time

The calibrations use estimates from models 3B, 3C and 3D, where the risk of a transition begins at age 18. The failure function is calculated at ages 25, 30 and 35 to coincide with the groups in Table 1. The computed probabilities averaged across observations suggest a 3.2–4.2, 2.4–3.2 and 2.3–3.2 percentage point reduction respectively in homeownership transitions. These simulations assume that rents do not adjust and may overstate the impact of borrowing restrictions. When the relative rent and housing user cost ratio is fixed at 1996 levels, the probabilities barely change.

sec.title: 8. Conclusion
sec.p: This study confirms Holmans’ (2001, 2005) findings that later transitions rather than exits from the tenure are responsible for the decline in young adult homeownership rates in Britain in the 1990s. Its main contribution is identifying that binding credit constraints caused by increases in house prices combining with lenders’ mortgage criteria played a part, in addition to demographic factors and shifts in the income distribution. Our simulations suggest that tighter constraints reduced their homeownership transitions by about 3 percentage points and that changes in relative housing tenure costs were less important as an explanation than being credit constrained.

Since the advent of the ‘credit crunch’, lending issues have become topical. Despite quantitative easing policies, lenders have continued adopting stricter criteria which have impacted disproportionately on potential FTBs. In turn, this is likely to have significantly affected transactions activity as FTBs are required to complete ‘chains’.

Government’s ability to help FTBs financially or to intervene in the market is hampered by its ‘structural’ deficit. Since credit restrictions delay rather than permanently prevent homeownership transitions, and other factors are influencing young adults to rent, it might be more viable for the government to encourage new investment in the private rented sector. The buy-to-let market recovered in 2010, but continued rises in real rents suggest that a response by this sector alone might not be enough. New investment might lead to more construction.

Families are increasingly assisting younger members’ transitions to homeownership. Transfers can be gifts or loans, but little is known about their influence on behaviour—the extent that they are used to reduce the deposit requirement or to consume more housing services and whether the young are discouraged from saving. Family transfers are likely to be funded from previous gains in housing equity. Reinvestment could lead to families with too much wealth ‘tied up’ in housing, as well as adding to demand pressures which reduce homeownership affordability in the longer term. Social mobility could be hindered from the resulting greater concentration of housing wealth among higher socioeconomic groups. More research on family wealth transfer and its wider implications should be undertaken, and perhaps also on policies to discourage it or to encourage investment in alternative assets.

The ‘credit crunch’ will not last indefinitely. Although future lending criteria may be more conservative than in the past, house prices are expected to return to trend growth. Long-term housing supply policies are still important and it is a concern that construction is still at very low levels in early 2011. Rises in house prices following economic recovery may be rapid, worsening homeownership affordability and exacerbating credit constraint problems.

The possible sample selection problem associated with left-sided truncation due to young adults already owning a home is not considered here. Our attempt to address this issue by incorporating a sample selection probit equation encountered problems in achieving convergence in the likelihood function. Under the caveat of achieving a local convergence, the results indicated that there was no significant correlation between the probit selection equation and the logit duration model, i.e there is no sample selection problem.
